awd_titl_txt: EPCN: Enhancing the Modeling, Simulation, and Visualization of Large-Scale Electric Grids Utilizing Detailed Synthetic Power Grids and Data Sets
awd_abstract_narration:
The high voltage electric grid plays a critical role in the day-to-day functioning and welfare of society, while supporting other major infrastructure as well. Tremendous research and development efforts are needed for improved grid design and operations to ensure reliability in the face of ever-changing load and generation characteristics, natural disasters, and evolving electricity markets.  Electric grid research is heavily dependent upon access to high fidelity electric grid models and datasets.  However, much of the crucial information about the design and operation of actual electric grids is considered confidential, and hence not publically available and often not even available to researchers in the field.  The proposed project aims to meet this need by developing and applying high quality, synthetic electric grid models and datasets that represent the complexities of actual electric grids, but contain no information about real grids and hence can be made publicly available.  The project results should be helpful to researchers and educators in the electric power area, and also to industry practitioners in training new engineers to solve problems facing the grid.   Another important aspect of this project is the results will be made publicly available for the benefit of the many different groups of people interested in learning more about the electric grid including researchers and educations in a wide variety of different fields that depend upon the electric grid, and the public. 
 
The goal of this project is to advance research and development in many domains by providing modeling and computational analytics associated with simulations of large-scale synthetic electric grids. The modern power grid is continuously generating large volumes of data, such as from phasor measurement units (PMUs). With the right analytics and measurements, it is possible to monitor system health, detect disturbances, and predict events such as outages.  The project has four main parts.  First, to build on the network creation methodology with detailed modeling to allow for extended time dynamic simulations and generating realistic synthetic data. The detailed modeling will include sub-transmission networks, protection system elements, cyber infrastructure, and enhanced dynamics of system elements.  Second, to leverage the synthetic grids from the first task to develop improved algorithms and models for a real-time simulation. Several new computational enhancements will be needed at this stage, with a goal being to innovate through adventurous, potentially transformative techniques that greatly extend conventional power system dynamic simulation. Third, to create synthetic and hence public data sets that reflect the complexity, and often errors, that would be obtained from actual devices such as from PMUs.   Last, to take the outcomes of the first three parts and develop interactive, multi-user simulation scenarios.   There will be a major education and research component to this. Improved visualization of the system parameters and results will also be explored to help with improved decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project improved the quality of synthetic test systems and datasets used for benchmarking algorithms in electric power systems research. This was accomplished by first creating high-fidelity synthetic, combined transmission and distribution (T&D) systems, while additional techniques were developed to model realistic load benefit data, generator cost curves, and synthetic PMU data for the synthetic grids.  Synthetic hourly time series of bus-level load and renewable generation were developed using publicly available data to represent different operating conditions of transmission systems.  Synthetic generator cost curves were developed to model realistic load benefit curves and generator costs for the synthetic grids. The synthetic grids were also augmented with Remedial Action Schemes (RAS) to add another element of complexity and realism to them. For other these, and other synthetic power system networks, an algorithm was developed for automatically modeling, tuning, and validating dynamic performance within large-scale synthetic grid cases with a high penetration level of inverter-based renewable sources.

These combined synthetic transmission and distribution systems were used for coupled infrastructure simulations, such as electric vehicle studies. For the coupled grid and transportation modeling, the EV load is derived from traffic simulation on an hourly basis and superimposed on this hourly load time series, after an appropriate mapping between transportation network nodes and grid substations.  Dynamic traffic assignment and charging models were used in the transportation network simulations to estimate the hourly electric vehicle (EV) energy consumption over a day.

Additionally, other transmission-only synthetic grids were used to assess the feasibility of connecting the actual Eastern and Western grids synchronously through AC ties, with a focus on the dynamic aspects. To improve simulation times for these large, continental-scale electric grid models, multi-rate integration methods were developed and used to decrease computational time. Smaller time steps were used to capture the system behavior associated with fast states and a larger time step for slow states, and this method was shown to have higher accuracy than the single-rate method. In order to evaluate the robustness of the grid under contingencies and identify the critical components under the specified operational conditions, a method for contingency analysis screening was developed based on the concept of Group Betweenness Centrality (GBC) that measures the impact of multiple components in electric power grid. Line outage distribution factors (LODF) are utilized to find the lines whose loss will have the highest impact on the power flow in the network.

Finally, several new visualization techniques were developed to enable better interpretation of results of simulating very large systems. Existing methods such as contouring and geographic data views were leveraged and several enhancements were made using techniques such as Delaunay triangulation to summarize a large quantity of spatio-temporal information on grids spanning the whole country. Additionally, VAR Ready Reserves were developed: a bivariate geographic data view, which presents regional availability of reactive power reserves relative to current reactive power requirements.

 

Broader impacts: The synthetic grids were leveraged towards creating interactive simulation that can enable users (students or professionals) an experience in operating the grid. Both single and multi-user simulation scenarios were developed, each with a different application. Due to the challenging nature of informed decision making while handing contingencies, techniques were developed to give uses (grid operators, researchers, or students) access to tools such as sensitivity analysis, contingency analysis and security constrained optimal power flows. The main idea of the technique is to appropriately initialize a power flow solution from a dynamic simulation snapshot.  Techniques were presented for using visual storytelling as a means for communicating the results of analyses on very large systems. Such techniques serve applications in educational, academic, and industrial settings.

Additionally, power system analysis techniques were modified to directly include the impact of weather and climate data on electric grids, broadening the integration of the meteorological and climatological research communities.  By analyzing historical weather data conditions and trends, the electric grid?s performance was more accurately modeled, allowing for better preparation for future extreme weather conditions. The communication infrastructure of synthetic grids was also modeled to create a comprehensive cyber-physical model of the electric grid. This allows researchers and operators to have a better vision of power systems from both cyber and physical perspectives, as well as extends power system adversaries from the physical and data domains to the cyber domain.

Finally, the test cases created as part of this project promote the highest quality of power systems research and cross-validation, and allow researchers to test the scalability of methods that previously could only be tested publicly on small systems. On a societal level, improved algorithms can lead to better technologies and solutions that are more robust, scalable and hence more effective in addressing problems of large-scale power grids.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2022
Modified by: Thomas Overbye
